titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. I came into Boston this morning in the Stage, with young Mr: Sewall— I called on Mr: Quincy, and settled accounts with him. Dined with Coll: Humphreys, and a small party of Gentlemen— Among whom was Mr: Ogilvie— We pass’d most of the Evening at Mr: Shaw’s Office—

2. Attended at 10 this morning a meeting of the Directors of the Middlesex Canal, at Dr: Dexter’s— Having been some time detained I was there late— Some business was transacted; but I did not very well understand it— Mr: D. Everett called upon me at my house; and I had some conversation with him— I had several times attempted to see him without success— In the Evening, I called to attend Mr: Ogilvie’s Oration, but could not get a place— I afterwards spent an hour at the Athenaeum.

3. We had this day, company to dine with us; consisting of Messrs: Ogilvie, Humphreys, Emerson, Buckminster, Dawes, R. G. Amory, B. Joy, Hall, Sumner, B. Welles, G. Blake, Shaw, and Captain Hull—and Miss Louisa Davis the Solicitor General’s daughter— Mr: and Mrs: W. Foster junr: and Mr: De Grand were here in the Evening— The entertainment of this Company employed the whole day so that I had no leisure time for any thing else.

4. My brother was in town this morning— I saw him only for a few minutes at my office. Mr: Hall called and shewed me a short letter he had just received from Dr: Eustis— This Evening I went with the Ladies, and heard Mr: Ogilvie deliver again his Oration against duelling— The room was crowded— He also recited several short poetical extracts— I am writing on politicks—

div.p: 5. After passing the morning at home, and taking an early dinner I walked to Cambridge— Attended the Declamation at 2. O’Clock and at 3. Read my 15th: lecture— Called in the interval for a few minutes at Dr: Waterhouse’s— Walked home afterwards with Dr: Welsh— About half an hour at my Office, and Evening at home.

6. Mr: J. Gardner and Mr: Hall were at my Office this morning— My brother came to town for me, and as I was engaged to dine with the Ladies at Mr: G. Blake’s, which detained us untill late in the Evening, my brother agreed to lodge this Night in town, and go out in the morning— The Company at Mr: Blake’s was large— The greater part, Ladies— Dr: Earle of Philadelphia was there.

7. My brother lodged at my house, and this Morning I went with him to Quincy— Heard, morning and afternoon a young Mr: Bartlett, from Cambridge— Remainder of the day, and Evening at my father’s— I read some passages from Sir Josiah Child’s discourse upon trade, and part of a volume of Buffon’s Natural History.

8. Returned to Boston this Morning in the Stage— At My Office— Dr: Waterhouse called upon me, and dined with me— He is in great distress, and I know not how he can get extricated from his difficulties— Mr: Gallison left my Office— He is going to enter one in the County of Essex— Mr: D. Everett called upon me this afternoon— Mrs: Adams and Catherine pass’d the Evening at our neighbour, Mr: Foster’s.

9. Dr: Waterhouse called upon me again this morning— He thinks of going to Washington— At four this afternoon the Directors of the Market Association had a meeting at Mr: Dyer’s Room— We chose Mr: Knapp senior Superintendant for building the Hall, with authority to make contracts, and instructions to begin as soon as possible— Evening at home— Mr: L. Foster was here about an hour—

10. I go later than I ought to my Office, because I waste much time unprofitably in my chamber— This day I was at my Office only from 12. to 2.— Afternoon at home— Evening walk in the Mall, and club at Dr: Spooner’s— Mr: Quincy was there, and goes on to Congress the day after to-morrow.

11. This forenoon at my Office I was engaged in signing certificates of Stock in the Boylston Market Association, for Messrs: Dyer and Reed— And this afternoon at a meeting of the Directors, upon a proposal to contract for the whole building— It was left at the discretion of Mr: Knapp the Superintendant, who appeared averse to engaging the whole by a single contract— In the Evening I was with my wife and Catherine Johnson, at a party, chiefly of Ladies at Dr: Danforth junrs.— The Dr: himself was out of town— I played Cards with Mrs: Knox, Mrs: P. Smith of New-York, and Mr: B. Greene.

12. Rainy morning— I went in the Stage to Cambridge— Dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s. Attended the Declamation at 2— The performers were numerous— Last appearance at this exercise of the Senior Class— I walk’d home; and pass’d the Evening mostly at writing, in my chamber— Heard George read, morning and Evening.

13. The remainder of my books came in this morning from Quincy— They have been pack’d up in boxes twelve complete years; and I have never had an opportunity to open them— Even now, I have not room for my whole library in my house; and am apprehensive I never shall— My brother came into town, and left the Chaise for me to return with to Quincy; he goes himself with his wife who has pass’d the week at Haverhill, and is now return’d, in another Chaise— I went out this Evening, and took George with me—
14. Heard Mr: Fisk of Cambridge, morning and afternoon— He also dined at my father’s— I pass’d part of the day in my brother’s Office; reading— The remainder in conversation with my father.

15. Thayer’s Stage from Quincy having broken down on Saturday in going out from Boston, and not being yet repaired, My father took us with him in a Chaise to the turnpike leading to the South-Boston Bridge— We walked the remainder of the way home— Soon after I got home, Mr: De Cabre called upon us; on a visit from Baltimore— I went for half an hour to my Office— Mr: B. Joy, called there, and invited me to dine with him on Wednesday with Judge Livingston, who is in town.— This afternoon I attended to the staking out of our lot for the Market Hall— Mr: Ogilvie and Mr: De Grand pass’d the Evening and supp’d with us— We sat conversing upon poetry, criticism and philosophy untill after Midnight.

16. Mr: Boylston called upon me, and desired me to see Mr: Dexter on the subject of a compromise between him, and the town of Boston— He shewed me also an anonymous letter which he had received.— I dined and spent the Evening with Mr: G. Blake, and a small party of Gentlemen— Judge Livingston was of the Company— Captain Hull came in after dinner, and invited us to go to-morrow on board the Chesapeake.

17. The town of Boston this day chose thirty-seven members to represent them in the General Court— I did not attend the meeting— At 11. this morning, I went in company with Judge Livingston, Judge Davis, and Mr: Blake, in Captain Hull’s barge, on board the Chesapeake frigate— We found her in the most perfect order— We then went on board the Wasp sloop of War, Captain Robinson, which returned last Evening from a cruize— She was also in very good order— Though not quite so completely as the Chesapeake— On our return we landed for a quarter of an hour on Castle-Island with Coll: Boyd who accompanied us— We found them here, not quite so well prepared— About 3. P.M. we got back to town, dined, and pass’d the Evening at Mr: B. Joy’s, with a Company of about 15 gentlemen.

18. Mr: Boylston was again at my Office this morning, and shewed me a second anonymous letter to him— I settled the payments on the shares I have taken in the Market Association, and discharged the mortgage I had taken of Mr: Dyer. In the Evening I went with Mrs: Adams and Catherine to hear a recitation of Mr: Ogilvie, with an Oration upon Beneficence— At the Theatre; Mr: De Cabre came home with us; but made a short stay— Mrs: Adams was unwell.

19. After passing the former part of the day at my Office, and the afternoon in my chamber, I was engaged the Evening with a company of about 30 ladies and Gentlemen who supp’d with us— Mrs: Knox sent an excuse— Mr: W. Gray and his family were here— The ladies made some Music. Mr: De Cabre stayed untill after Midnight.

20. My book-cases were brought home, but will not have room for half the books which I have lately received from Quincy. My library is now, almost entirely collected together, but proves to me more and more the absurdity of pretending to own a library without a large Estate to keep it in countenance— The apartment necessary to hold a large collection of books must be of a size, which no other than a rich man can spare from the other parts of his dwelling house; and the manner in which I am compell’d to crowd my books together leaves me little more use for them than if I had no library at-all— We walked this Evening in the Mall— Mr: De Cabre and Mr: De Grand joined us, and came home and supp’d with us— They stayed untill Midnight. This has been an idle week— The species of Dissipation into which I seem insensibly to be sliding is of a dangerous kind— It requires to guard against it a vigour of Resolution, which I am somewhat apprehensive of summoning, lest it should fail me; yet I perceive that it threatens the welfare of my family, and my own final reputation.

21. In the forenoon we all heard Mr: Tuckerman of Chelsea, at Mr: Emerson’s— Returning from meeting we met in the Mall, judge Livingston and Mr: G. Blake— Judge Livingston apologized, for not coming on Friday, as he had intended to leave town the day before. In the afternoon we went to the Roman Catholic Church, where we heard Mass and a very short Sermon by Mr: Chevreux— His English composition is very good but the accent of his pronunciation is french to an unusual degree. It was Whitsunday; a considerable festival, which lengthened the Services of the day— I read two Sermons of Massillon’s Petit Carême—and pass’d the leisure of the day in my chamber— Mr: Everett spent the Evening with us.

22. The forenoon I pass’d at my Office— Mr: Boylston called there with a third anonymous letter, to which he wrote an answer. The afternoon I was in my chamber, and began reading Auger’s Translation of Demosthenes— Or rather his preliminary discourse. Mr: De Cabre and Mr: De Grand was here in the morning— Mrs: W. Foster in the Evening.

23. Mr: De Grand called upon me at 6. this morning, and I went with him and George and bathed at the new baths near the Baptist Meeting House— The steps which were there last Summer have been broken away— About 8 this Morning Mr: Knapp called upon me, and said the Corner Stone of the Market-Hall was to be laid this day at 11. O’Clock, and some of the Gentlemen wished that I would come and lay it; to which I consented— About an hour afterwards he called again and said that there would be a number of Gentlemen collected there; and some refreshments on the ground adjoining, belonging to Mr: Reed— That he wished me on laying the Stone, to make a short address, to the witnesses present, to which I also agreed— At 11. I went— There were about 60 or 70 persons present— Members of the Association, and some others— Mr: Gore— Mr: Emerson & Mr: Holley were of the number— On laying the corner Stone, I address’d a few words to the company; after which we partook of the refreshments provided, and drank three or four toasts— At 12. I attended a meeting of the Directors of Middlesex Canal, at Mr: W. Payne’s Office, in the new Exchange Building— Some business was referr’d to a Committee of 3. Mr: Jos: Hall— Mr: J. L. Sullivan and myself— We agreed to meet at Mr: Hall’s Office at 4. this afternoon— My brother called on me after dinner— So did Mr: Knapp, with Mr: Andrews & Mr: Williams two of our Directors to ask a copy of my short address for publication— I had sent one to Mr: Emerson at his request— I attended at Mr: Hall’s Office at the time, and we soon agreed upon a report which Mr: Hall drew, and we all signed— I had afterwards some conversation with Mr: Hall— He says Mr: Gore told him, that Chief Justice Parsons strongly urged him Gore, in his War Report to the last Legislature, to introduce a formal justification of the British Orders of Council of 11. Novr: 1807— Which Gore refused on the ground that it would be too inconsistent with the principles to which he had heretofore pledged himself— I returned and pass’d the Evening at home— Mrs: Knox and her daughter Swan took tea with Mrs: Adams, and left us between 9 and 10. Mrs: W. Foster junr: and her daughter Melite stayed about half an hour longer— Mr: De Cabre stayed and continued music with the ladies untill past one in the morning.

24. My brother and his wife came to town yesterday, and this afternoon after calling at my house, returned to Quincy— Mr: G. A. Cushing called at my Office on business with Mr: D’Wolfe, a director of the Bristol Insurance Company— I went with W. S. Shaw to Mr: Alston’s painting Room, and saw some of his pictures and drawings.— Dr: Waterhouse came and shewed me the draught of a letter which he proposes sending to the Secretary of the Treasury— I had several applications for the houses which I have advertised, and Mrs: Knox engaged to take that adjoining mine— I also engaged that now occupied by Gurney— I called this morning upon Mr: Jackson the Treasurer of the College— J. Gardner was at my house early in the Evening— The Club was at my house— Mr: Emerson, Judge Davis, Dr: Spooner and Dr: Dexter, and Mr: E. Gray only attended— Mr: De Cabre and Mr: Ogilvie came also by my invitation.

25. Attended at 12 O’Clock at the State House, Academy’s Room, the Committee of the Trustees of the Hopkins donation— Mr: Dawes and Judge Davis were there; but were not ready to report— Judge Dawes agreed to see Mr: Gannett on Monday, and be ready with a report on Tuesday Morning— Dr: Kirkland, and Dr: Lathrop came in afterwards— I called at the Athenaeum— Mr: D. Everett was at my house this afternoon— In the Evening we went and took George to hear Mr: Ogilvie’s Oration on the progress of Society—with which I was not very well pleased— He afterwards recited the Death of Marmion, from Scott’s Poem— We saw there Mr: De Cabre and Mr: Casaux. Mr: De Cabre came home and pass’d an hour with us— He sets out on his return to Washington on Saturday.

26. I was but a short time this forenoon at my Office— At about 1/2 past 2 Mr: William Gray called upon me, and I went with Mrs: Adams and Catherine, in his Carriage with him to Mr: Boylston’s at Jamaica-Plains to dinner— Mr: Boylston’s son’s wife, with her two children, and a Mr: Benton her brother are now with him, lately arrived from Carolina— We returned in the Evening, and took a walk in the Mall— Mr: De Cabre was here and took his leave— He is going to-morrow morning.

27. The third number of the review of Ames’s Works was this day published— Mr: Jos: Hall, called at my Office this forenoon; and mentioned them to me— But very little notice is taken of them any where— They sent home my Son John from Quincy, this day— My brother took him out there last Wednesday week— This Evening I went out there, and took George with me, to spend the Election week there—

28. This forenoon I was detained from Meeting by a thunder shower, which came on just at the time of Service— I attended however in the afternoon, and heard Mr: Whitney— Evening at the Office and with my father— My Mother is very unwell— Confined to her chamber and almost to her bed, with St: Antony’s fire.— I heard George read French, in the Magasin des Enfans.

29. Returned to Boston this morning, in the Stage, leaving George for the week at Quincy— At my Office— Met Judge Dawes and Judge Davis there, on the Committee of the Hopkins Trustees— We agreed upon a report— Mr: Munroe, one of the Editors of the Patriot called upon me this afternoon— I passed the Evening chiefly in my chamber.

30. Early this morning at Market— The meeting of the Hopkins Trustees was adjourned to the Academy’s Room at 10. Met accordingly; and without accepting the Report of the Committee, voted what it recommended— At 11. was the meeting of the Academy. It was well attended— Most of the Officers of the last year, were re-elected— I effected with some difficulty two changes among the Counsellors— There were several communications— One important one from Mr: Godon, on the mineralogical character of the ground in the vicinity of Boston— The meeting adjourned after 2. P.M. My father— Mr: Ware, Mr: Farrar, Mr: Willard, Mr: Hedge— Mr: Freeman, Dr: Prince of Salem and Mr: Mellen of Cambridge, dined with me— In the Evening, my father, and Louisa Smith returned home to Quincy— I met Mr: Boylston this morning, and he came with me to call on my father— In the Evening, I met and walked a couple of hours with Mr: J. Gardner.

31. This was the day of the annual election— And in the choice of Officers by the two branches of the Legislature it appears that the federal majority remains in the same State, substantially, as it stood last year— There were only 37 Senators present— And the votes for President, were 20. for Otis 17. for Dana— In the house of Representatives there were 576. Members— The votes for Speaker were, for Bigelow 306. for Morton 269— The plurality consisting precisely of the Boston seat—37.— The Election Sermon was preached by Dr: Osgood of Medford— I did not hear it, but was informed that he was very abusive upon my father and upon me— No doubt he was chosen for that purpose— I called with Mr: A. Welles at Dr: Warren’s and saw the procession pass— I was at my Office in the forenoon, and from 4. in the afternoon untill dusk— In the Evening I attended the club at Mr: Buckminster’s— It was not very fully attended— The gentlemen were all disapproving and admiring the Sermon— Mr: Emerson told me after coming out, that there were two or three Sentences in it, for which Osgood ought to be hanged.

Day. Continues much as the last Month— Excepting that I have employed during this month, much of my time, in reviewing the Works of Mr: Ames, compiled by a number of his friends. This is itself a sort of dissipation, and I know not, whether it will do any good.
